								I am a Chinese guy and I'm so glad that there is one game about China and its long and complicated history. For a long time, Chinese history and culture seems to be a mystery for the western world, which makes lots of troubles in the international affairs. Now, there is one bridge that might fix the gap. I am so happy about it, even though it's only a game. (Yes, I know the game Romance of 3 kingdoms, but they are different. In this game, I think we could experience more Chinese culture and history while Romance of 3 kingdoms is more like an epic, a novel full of lengendary heros. Heros are more important in that game instead of history and culture.)As for the game, I think it seems like the combination of Civilization series and Total War series.It looks very complicated, a real strategy game. And as for Chinese history and culture in the game, the details are accurate. It starts from the first dynasty of China, Shang, and goes to dynasty Zhou, and then waring state period, including all the major states in the real Chinese history, even Xianbei. For culture part, you could develop Taoism, Buddisim, Confucianism and even YinYang which really suprises me since not many western people know it.  And for the video performance, it's really cool. You could zoom in and out in the game and check all the details of your city and your people. You could see the farmers working in the field and the merchant working in the city, all in details.I just played the game for half an hour and didn't fight in any war right now but I am quite looking forward to it since in Chinese history, people developed lots of strategies about how to fight in the war, how to defeat enemy effectively and wisdomly. The famous and well-known example is the book 'the Art of War' by Sunzi, who was born in Spring and Autumn Period, 550BC. So I am quite curious about that whether we could use strategies in the war and get some benefits from them, use militory wisdom to defeat enemies effectively . I think this game would become a masterpiece if there are more improvements in the future. For example, the game would be better if it has a mini map, an open CG and more tutorials for beginners because it is kind of complicated at the first glance. And there are also translation problems, comparing to the history facts. For example, in the game there is one tribe which is called 'Dog Rong'. Actually this is kind of funny since it looks like the combination of English and Chinese pinyin,'Dog' is English while 'Rong' is Chinese...Actually, it is 'Quan Rong' in Chinese, even though 'Quan' in Chinese means 'dog' in English. In the game, there are lots of these phenomena, the combinations of English and Chinese pinyin makes the game funny for the people who know Chinese history.And also I suggest that it would be better if this game has Madarin version because in China, there are many steam players right now. All of them will be very happy to play such a game. This will also solve the traslation problem. English speakers do not need to read Chinese pinyin which might be hard and inconvenient for them since they might not know how to read Chinese pinyin, not to mention the meaning of Chinese pinyin. For example, in English version, the game could use 'Go' instead of 'Weiqi', 'Taoism' instead of 'Daoism'. They are same things, but clearly, Go and Taoism would be better for English speaker to undertand what they are.Anyway, I will recommend this game to the players who love strategy game and the players who are interested in Chinese history and culture. Excellent work.

								It's bad. Real bad.At a bird's eye view, it's a Civ clone, but only in that you can build cities at various hexes on the map and make your way through a simplistic tech tree that effects one or two stats.When looking deeper, it is an empty shell of a Civ game, chalk full of bad design decisions, illogical behavior, bad AI, and the most abysmal combat I've ever seen in a strategy game.Battle is automated. The player has no control over what occurs during battle. That alone takes half the potential strategy out of a strategy title. They make you watch the battle take place in a scene like total war reenacted by your kid sister with stick figure dollies.During those battles you'll see:Troops run through each other, run away into the terrain, run in circles...The AI runs through your full stack army with one troop and takes your city...Your movement gets blocked by continual spam of beaten up worthless units....and other various nonsensical behavior.You'll be saying "WTF?" at your monitor over and over, not understanding the mechanics of movement, retreat, and combat, because they don't make sense and they don't match what the help says.I made videos and asked on the forums to get to the bottom of it.

Early Access Review
								At its current state, Oriental Empires is not worth the investment************************************************************************(Edited Spelling)Summary: The ideas are there, but there are tons of factors that make those ideas near impossible to experience.The game seems to be designed to bloom at some point, making the one more turn feel come to mind. Yet there are a lot in the way, dragging the experience down to a slow, slow drag.Almost like the developer is buying time, letting the gamer live on dreams and imagination alone. I have to wait 200 turns to test other factions? When I do get there, will the clunky animation, path-finding problems, lacking diplomacy and economic options be solved? It would make for one of the best games of 2016, but the early access stamp whispers of yet another game being left in development: until pigs fly.************************************************************************Full Review:It's a fun game, and it has potential, but potential has come to  mean nothing for consumers.Empty promises being the standard in the industry.What I hear, is that the game is only lacking multiplayer, and that the single player experience is more or less complete. Now, ironing out bugs and polishing, are what we can expect. Yet there are some flaws that go beyond polishing and bug reports.If the problems are somehow fixed, I will of course make this a positive review, but as things stand, the game is lacking, and left as is, it is simply just another good idea that wasn't given the time and love it needed. It needs to go back into the forge.What needs to be mended:*Combat*Combat needs to be reworked on many levels. It feels rushed and slapped together.The combat AI is really bad. Making total war vanilla combat AI look amazing in comparison.Path-finding is a big, if not the biggest problem. Units will run around aimlessly, run the wrong way: making the choices of "battle plans" (harass, charge, flank etc) seem to have no, to little impact at all. You don't control your soldiers like in total war, battles are fought in a cinematic fashion as you end your turn. You can decide what way your troops face, number or ranks, and each units “battle plans”. In theory it is awesome, but what unfolds looks like a pc game to movie by Uwe Boll with the budget of a bag of chips. Beside clunky, limited animations and god awful path finding, combat also has some really bad design decisions lingering. Near game breaking.As an example: single units can take a settlement of four units.A city has four gates, but if a fight is lost at only one of those gates, the battle is over and the city is lost. Now if I have three good units, with one sad sack bamboo spear peasant mob tasked with guarding one gate, I feel hatred for the game when said, "sad sack mob" is defeated by a unit that could never best even one of the other three units guarding the other gates. What the hell are the other soldiers doing? Another example:A large amount of solders should be able to interfere with one unit mobs in near hexes, in friendly territory at the very least. Having a large army of trained soldiers, just watching enemies burn the rice fields around them is always frustrating. It's their lifeblood, their money, and their people being savaged. Units jogging around the city, rice paddy hopping (in hexes), to catch looters is ridiculous. It makes no sense. As long as soldiers are present outside the city walls, or garrison, they should be able to defend the rice fields. Why you might ask? There is a meter measuring revolt risk in percentage. When you draft the peasants to fight off the looters, the meter increases. When the fields get burned around the sad sack mob you call an army, and the city lacks food, the revolt risk increases to the extreme. Then if you manage to handle all the damn looters, and ask the peasants to re-cultivate the burned out rice fields, the meter increases as they feel overworked. Making a few single unit looters, a very likely reason for a revolt and the city being lost.If you're lucky you manage to re-cultivate in time without any revolts: I swear, you will see bandits popping up as the revolt risk is high. And what do you think they do?Paddy hex hopping until either your population, or your sanity turn against you.*Actual look and feel of the combat*This is important, as it is a very big part of the game. Cinematic war, you only look to see your men fight, you can't control them during the fighting, so this being poorly polished gives the game a really ugly feel.Units facing the wrong way and shooting arrows through their backs. Chariots spinning to unheard disco tunes. Soldiers running through each other. Zooming in to see fighting being clunkier than a made-for-tv-movie-vhs-tape that someone paid you to see. Units are either marching, or having no idea what animation they are supposed to do, as the swing, stop, spin, and run to the horizon, only to come back like nothing happened. Is this an example of a compete single player experience? The combat looks awful. Animations are lacking.If this was an alpha, and not a game that will soon be released I would understand, but this feels like a cash grab. Is multiplayer with or without the civilization management?If it's only the fighting and war part of the game, the clunky animations and sad sack combat animations will spell doom for multiplayer in a heartbeat.*Diplomacy*The ghosts of total war whisper my name. It's limited to the extreme. This is a game about building a civilization and waging war. Add more options! The diplomacy ai is clearly a b-stard child of total war sneaking into the production. I ask for peace, and I'm refused by a stronger enemy. I get it, I'm there for the taking. What I don't get is why that enemy would ask for peace the next turn and add one single gold coin to the bargain. "I could destroy you, and that is crazy,  here is a gold coin, call me maybe".*Economics and the Tech Tree*A lot of buildings cost too much to maintain. Soldiers too. Having markets and bazaars costs more than the economy they provide. While the maintenance of each building makes for a beggar king. The Tech Tree is there to suck the years out of your life with very little change. There's a lot of interesting text to come with each advancement.  Fun to read once, but providing little impact.

								This can be a good 4X strategy game for some people, as it strikes a balance between complexity and enjoyablility (in other words, not too easy, not too hard), so it won't be a regret if you buy it. However, for those who are looking for a decent game experience, I cannot recommend this game due to several reasons:NOTE: The following reasons are ordered by what I think is important. However, if you are concerned about possible false advertising, please make sure you read part 4.1. Lack of tutorial / informative gamepediaIn a turn based strategy you always want to know what's going on as well as the reason behind it. You also want to make sure that what you are doing is what you think you are doing. These require an informative tutorial or gamepedia.If you want to take down an enemy city, you want to know what you need to bring, how a siege can be successful / unsuccessful, what orders to give so that your troops siege the city instead of sitting outside of it. But the game doesn't teach you these things. You have to find out yourself.2. Unpolished UIWhile UI isn't part of the strategy, it does affect your game experience. For now, the game UI is kind of messy, and sometimes you need to click a lot to achieve what you want to do.3. Not really ChineseThe reason I bought this game it that I am Chinese and I wanted to see what game developers can make out of a Chinese topic. But to my disappointment this game is just another 4X game with some Chinese names and Chinese artwork. There's nothing in the game that is unique to Chinese culture or Chinese philosophy.Just change the names and artwork and you get a Roman Empire game, a medieval game, a fantasy game, a space alien game... Well, you get me.4. Grand strategy vs Formation tacticsThe game advertised itself as "Civ meets Total War" (I'm sure I read it somewhere; it's not on the store page right now - maybe they changed it). It's certainly an interesting idea, but it didn't really work out. In Civ you manage the grand strategy, give orders, and leave the real fighting to your armies. In Total War you manage the grand strategy in the world map, and manage the tactics in the battle map.This game tries to include both grand strategy and formation tactics within the world map, which is rather a bad move because it doesn't allow much depth for formation tactics, which then makes the formation tactics element useless. I haven't changed any formation option for once, and it's pretty safe to engage the enemy with default options when you have superior numbers. I guess it's only useful when you are trying to get out of a difficult situation, but again, (see part 1.) the game doesn't really tell you what you should do to get the advantage you need.Also, don't be fooled by those screenshots that are close-in to armies, as if those armies are being controlled in-battle (like in Total War). No. Everything is set up before you hit next turn, and you cannot change a thing after it. You can only watch, which is not interesting at all.

Early Access Review
A 4X tribute to the East, Oriental Empires provides hours of strategic TBS gameplay for fans of the civilization building strategy games. Though you see elements of Civ V and Age of Empires games at times, don’t expect the game to be true to either franchise. Instead, what you find is an experience that comes across as a comic book combined with a board game from another era, and spawned into digital format; born again in some alternate continent’s code of conduct. If you are looking for something different in the world of 4X, this may be for you. At this time, it released in Early Access, only because the multiplayer is not finished. So, only single player is available at this point.Art & Music: In a beautiful world of mountains & rivers, laid out on a map that allows you to panoramically zoom to any degree in or out, the Empires of the Far East come to life in the beautiful scenes that seem to be reminiscent of charcoal drawings. It’s an art style sure to be appealing to everyone. When you zoom in, you become a part of the village & the daily lives of the people. Yet, when you zoom out you see the whole countryside and can plan & plot combat moves & colonization. If you continue to zoom out, you can even see other empires and the cities they are building. All of this beautiful scenery is augmented with lovely tunes from the Orient that are as high-quality as those made by Kairis for Paradox Studio’s lovely music dlc’s. The tunes are lively & provide ambience that certainly makes the gameplay enjoyable.Graphics:With simplified graphics reminiscent of This War of Mine, Oriental Empires makes the story come alive on a map in an imaginative way that can be intensely pleasing for many people. It could be seen as quaint, or maybe retro. It certainly calls to mind playing old Stratego & Risk boardgames. This may not appeal to some gamers, especially the simple characters, who appear as 2d in the bottom corner, & fight in stiff 3d scripted forms. It’s certainly not a Triple A title, but it manages to bring a sense of atmosphere to the world of the Orient. Narrative:The storyline progresses through 5 eras of Chinese & Mongolian history. You are able to play as different factions, and you have some control over when you move into the next era, based on which tech you choose. The techs are limited, but provide story-rich choices to the way you will develop your nation. Some narration appears between eras, and the voice acting is as great as the music. But, don’t expect a Western game set in the East. The game itself & the story are very Oriental in design. Mechanics:The combat allows you to plot all your moves, & then watch them play out before you. This forces you to plan for contingencies. You are able to change the way the units face at waypoints. You are able to select their fighting stance; whether defensive or offensive, in a variety of strategies. And, unlike most games, it seems often that the best method is to avoid conflict, and defend your villages. I’ve seen the raiders act just like huns; pillage, burn, run, &  while you chase after them, another unit is coming in behind to raid your unprotected village. The mechanics are not cookie cutter, and seem to be unique to the game, despite the fact that many components are shared by other 4X games. The tutorial needs work, though there are no bugs at all that I’ve seen. I like the way the advisor stays in the corner greyed out until you need her. Also, all of the overlays are unobtrusive, since they can be toggled individually to allow for great screen shots, which is very important to many people. I wish some of the bigger 4X titles could learn that idea. The biggest problem I see with the game for some is that you need to read the text info provided behind the question mark, in something similar to an infopedia to play the game. It’s one of those TL;DR things that some just won’t care to deal with. But, for me, I read everything from street signs to cereal box small print anyways. In the case of this game, you will probably need to read the more info area to proceed. Also, the advisor seems to offer advice periodically, just sometimes that advice seems to come after you need it instead of before. Pros: *Art style is very engaging*Combat is fun & fresh*Gameplay is realistic for the Far East territory*Interface is user-friendly with total control Cons:*Tutorial is scant leaving a learning curve*Graphics are simplistic *In EA until MP is completeI recommend Oriental Empires for those who enjoy fresh strategic turn-based gameplay set in particular historical locales. With combat and story features, there’s so much to enjoy in this game.

								Oriental Empire is the kind of game that I've wanted for a while. Yes, I would like to see some more out of it - and perhaps some tweaks as well: but with the short time I've spent playing it I've had a lot of fun! I've done everything from build an extensive trade network stretching from one side of the map to the other, engage in vicious primitive wars (Bronze age) and emerged victorious, and paid close attention to the little details in the map that make this game what it is.But what is this game?I would personally say that this game is a mixture of Civilization and Total War. You kind of get the best of both worlds. The randomized maps and building system of the Civilization games, with the up close and personal combat of Total War! Mind you you can't control your unit movements once they've engaged in a battle (so more like Civ?), but you can set their stances before they engage, as well as what kind of formation they will be fighting it. This combat makes for some epic clashes that can take place in an extensive battlefield that could stretch from the front gates of a city to the far outskirts of it!Though this all sounds really cool I think they're missing out on a few things: the big one being more on-the-map activity! This would be physical buildings with civilians working around them (maybe at the forge, barracks, ect.), a variety of different people - not just farmers, more animals roaming around (not just standing there), and natural disasters that we can actual see. The one thing that they did do very well is the on-map destruction caused by warfare! I also wouldn't mind seeing more commodities. The map feels very bare - with useful resources seemingly few and far between. Maybe as you advance through the ages more resources reveal themselves? However though it could improve, this Early Access title delivers with little/no bugs - and a fantastic time! Right now I'd give it a 8/10!Short list of features I'd like to see:- Dynasties- More resources- More on the map activity- more diplomatic options- unique play styles from different AI- more empire customization- Variety of different citizens (not just farmers and soldiers!)

								The tagline you see in most of the reviews here on steam is that this is “CIV + Total War set in China”. I’d say the first part of that tagline is inaccurate – this game does not much resemble Total War. If you really want a Total War style game set in China get Koei’s Romance of the Three Kingdoms series, with the caveat that those games are based on historical fantasy and not actual history. That said, Oriental Empires is a good game with interesting design plus a unique setting. Gameplay: In the Grand Campaign you explore a semi-random (resources are distributed differently each game but the map is fixed) map of China that starts in 1500BCE. There are many historically-flavored factions but the differences between them are small at the time of this review and each start with the same setup – a capital city in a fixed, historical, location, a settler, a commander and a faction leader who can also command. The biggest difference between factions is starting location.As you explore you’ll find resource deposits or points of interest your named characters can interact with similar to Elemental or Endless Legend. These points of interest can be positive or negative but at the moment variety seems limited. I’ve only encountered trait increase/decrease, money gain/lose, technology shortcut and map reveal events. I hope they add more variety and take more from Endless Legend/Elemental by including short quests. You’ll also encounter the other factions (no minor factions are present). After meeting a faction you can enter into diplomacy with them but I find the balance within the system to be poor. It doesn’t feel great when nations you meet quickly declare war, march about for a few turns, then accept peace if you offer them 1 gold. Maybe they just wanted the pride of saying they beat you, but with no buff/debuff apparent based on the outcome of a war it seems more likely that they haven’t finalized the faction relationship system yet. After the initial “we hate all our neighbors” round, it is easy to establish peace with everyone near you, especially if you start by offering to recognize a strong neighbor as Emperor – a decision I hoped would carry stronger penalties than a single point off my “authority”. The peace network seems to endure indefinitely (80+ turns in my second game), leading to a rather slow-paced early-mid game where you simply tech, settle new cities and explore. As you found new cities and grow your existing ones, you’ll want to balance a few different factors. Expansion is limited by two resources – you have a “recruitment pool” of units that refreshes periodically (Similar to Medieval 2) so you can’t simply spam settlers and you have the previously mentioned “authority” attribute, which must be higher than the number of settlements you own or you will face penalties to unrest. Authority can be increased via the research tree. Unrest is divided into “noble” and “peasant” unrest with the former being influenced mostly by authority and Edicts – special commands you can issue which enact empire-wide policy decisions and advance you into different ages. Peasant unrest is influenced by how many turns you’ve been giving your peasants tasks constructing buildings, farms, etc. and can be reduced by not issuing such orders for a few turns. If unrest gets too high you start to get bandit spawns, and if the unrest continues you may face a rebellion. There are two types, peasant and noble. If you approach a rebellious stack with your own army composed of 50% or more of the same class of unit there is a chance your army will defect! Your faction leader’s army will never defect however. I quite like this mechanic as it gives a strategic factor to what type of army you send rather than simply picking your strongest units. Cities themselves can be fairly easy to manage– there’s no “upkeep” for the city or population itself so just building farms and growing the population is a decent way to make a profit. Each settlement has a number of slots for buildings (expanding the settlement increases the number of slots) and some of these require upkeep. Don’t build more high-upkeep buildings than you can afford in the early game. There are also tile-based buildings, including mountain shrines, mines and river quays. Production buildings don’t seem to turn a profit until you’re able to integrate them into a trade network and be warned that trade, while profitable, takes a bit of time to build up. Trade is limited by distance but upgraded trade buildings can reach farther. Also, some Edicts have a high maintenance cost while others can introduce new taxes, both significantly affecting your income. Your cities are precious and can be lost to rebellion fairly easily (cities can rebel) but are generally secure from all but a concerted effort from enemy factions once you build defenses. Walls are very strong in this game and can only be overcome by ranged units and, later on, artillery. This defensive strength does contribute to the mid-game stagnation I’ve noticed – cities rarely change hands and wars are more about pillaging land and defeating armies than capturing territory. Armies in this game are composed of a few different types of units (no unique units for factions at the moment) basically divided into noble, peasant or trained/professional class infantry, cavalry and archers. Noble and peasant units can be recruited for free from cities and as mentioned there is a replenishing recruitment pool in each city which is influenced by building choices, technology and population. I tend to specialize only a couple of cities in recruitment as it costs a lot to maintain the buildings and units are only equipped with advanced weapons and armor when recruited. Professional units are useful for all purposes though they carry a high cost while peasant units are cheap and plentiful but weak and nobles are strong but limited in number. Units on the map can be stacked up to 8 on one tile and are influenced by the traits of a character if his bodyguard unit is part of the army.Combat in this is not Total-War style as so many have mentioned. Multiple stacks can participate in a battle, and battles take place on the regular game map (think Endless Legend). Battles are not manually controlled but you can set tactics and army-facing beforehand, giving you some influence over the course of the battle. The system reminds me of Endless Space. I’d like to see more factors come into play like bonuses for professional armies vs. peasants and so on, plus a clearer UI for setting up tactics. Exploration, City Management and War will take up about 90% of your time, but the other 10% isn’t wasted. Research in this game is conducted simultaneously via 4 mostly-separate research trees. I like the system but most technologies and bonuses are straightforward stat boosts or unit/building unlocks. I’d like to see more gameplay elements tied into research. As a note, unlike many other 4X games a full suite of diplomatic options are available from the start and don’t need to be researched. Overall Feeling: This is a slower 4X game than many others in the genre. There is a large emphasis on internal city management and minor wars compared to competitor’s emphasis on technology or outright destroying opponents. If you’re looking for an “exciting” 4X or total war style strategy on the battlefield you may find yourself disappointed. If you want a historically flavored nation-building game with diplomatic and military options, focused more on strategy than tactics, you may have a winner on your hands here. I for one have enjoyed my time playing Oriental Empires immensely and would recommended it provided you are 1) interested in the setting 2) looking for a slower-paced, city focused 4X rather than a combat-oriented one.

								(This first (but added after initial review): Since I am became convinced that the faults of this game are by design and not fixable (and since the developer seems to think that single player is done - making it unlikely that structural changes to core mechanics will even be attempted) I tried to get a refund. I didn't get it because I played the game for more than 2 hours. My fault for giving the game a second/third chance, I guess. If you don't want to run into the same trap just be aware that you have to make up your mind in the first two hours)If single player is indeed done and they are just working on multiplayer, then this is a bad game.Building buildings is a bad idea more often than not because the huge upkeep costs will ruin you. Even things like market places, which usually help build a working economy, seem to hurt your growth more than they help.The battles are very frustrating. There is no way to lock down enemy armies and they almost always survive the fight. Also the AI (which does all the moving and fighting for you) makes very dumb things... like ignore the enemy bandits that are pillaging your city (right next to your army) and instead attack the neutral player next to your OTHER city several hexes down. I've had to spend like 20 moves just hunting one bandit and I didn't even defeat him, he just retreated to somewhere else. I would really like to publicly execute that general and his entire army for incompetence, but the game doesn't even give you THAT option.Armies that lose their battle don't retreat to your city directly behind them, but instead to somewhere ~1.5 moves away from your city. Which puts you in trouble for next turn because your city is alone with whoever just routed you and you can't get back.And when you got an economy going by cleverly NOT building your cities, then peasant revolts turn 3 of your 9 cities in two turns (one of them your capital - which was fine a few turns before, so no idea what happened there). No warning or anything. And of course the peasants can afford military that you could only dream of (instant full stacked armies). Plus, what would you even use to reconquer? Your capital is the city that was built up to create armies.I mean not that a warning would help. You can't really do anything. I mean you could build a building for a few turns and then raze it after, but the helpful effects are negligible and the costs huge (and the whole idea of building a temple for a few turns to make the  peasants happy and then razing it for economic reasons is idiotic), Seriously, I had a very strong economy at one point, built an Taoist temple in every city, to make my peasants happy, and that alone completely tanked my entire economy.All in all the game continually expects you to make decisions, but all the data required to make those decisions is hidden from you. Like silk for example. Is it a good idea to produce silk? No idea. At this point I think it is probably ALWAYS a bad idea. Building it in every city will definitly ruin you. Maybe it will be feasible to build it once in your empire after you reach a certain size? Or maybe the only point when it is ever feasible is when you have a map buff for silk in one of your cities? But how would you know when? So right now I just avoid it... I mean what's the point of having so many buildings when almost all of them are designed as noobtraps?I am hoping that they will still work on single player because all in all this *could* be a very great game.The similarities with Civ end with the hexes, but the game is pretty much a carbon copy of TW games (right down to the end of turn gong) without user controlled battles (which I enjoyed less every TW game after Medieval II, so not a big loss there) and with faster turns (which is a HUGE plus).

Early Access Review
								This game is awesome. While reviews may be mixed and some can be rather scathing this is actually a very well done game.  It is done in the old style ala total war medieval 2 and civ 2 with more freeform and hardcore systems.  The city building seems to be a bit more like the upcoming civ 6 with a decentralized system rather than an internal system which allows the enviroment to vary your play a fair bit.  The map is dynamic in resources and "goody huts" which take place as encounter oppurtunities instead of huts.  However being a historical game the geography remains unchanged each game and depending on your faction choice your starting city will always be in the same place.  Cities expand thier borders not through culture or even through growth but instead through construction.  You have to build farmland to expand your city borders and the maximum distance of this is based on the settlement size which like medieval 2 is tied to population and the act of upgrading the town which also controls the number of buildings that can be supported and how many troops can be recruited at one time.  In this regard it is very much total war.That being said here are some breakdowns of things people have not noticed and have led to poor reviews:1. the game released like 3 days ago to early access and is very much playable despite this more so than most early access games ive played even years after they were released to early access.2. technology is performed by a 4 field system in which you constantly research 1 tech from each field at a time and some things in one field have pre-reqs in another field. some factions excel or suck at researching certain fields and events can cause the speed of research to rise and fall.3. combat is slightly unrefined but is also highly adaptive if you use it correctly.  I left some units in defend stance and told them to attack some archers who wanted to burn down my walls.  Sat there for a few minutes wondering why i lost 10 men and they just stood there.... yeah totally my fault.  More on combat later.4. techs provide a variety of benefits but can be broken down into 4 main effects. culture, authority, military and trade.Culture allows you to combat unhappiness by having a unfiied culture.  Events and tech increase these.  Authority let's you beat down those snobby nobles who dont like being controlled and effectively increase your city limit. Combat are techs that directly affect your combat options by adding or changing units.  Trade affects your ability to produce goods for internal trade or external trade.  Little tip on that research pottery first as it has no upkeep and provides pottery for internal trade early on.  Trade grows the longer it is operational so at first you lose money due to upkeep but pottery is pure profit.Now combat.  It seems this is most misunderstood even among those who spent all morning watching my stream.  Combat has a lot of variety in troop types and capabilities.  Spending time researching the movement speeds, morale levels, defense ability and attack ability is well worth it.  A low morale unit will break long before being killed.  Attaching a general to the army stack helps with this.  A unit that is high in defense ability will perform better in qa defense position but if you place them in defense and other units in attack the other units will move forward on the field and leave the defenders behind.  I hope they add a control for this to force like archers to stay behind defenders or they did and i haven't discovered how yet.  Facing also matters as a unit facing the wrong way will send less men into battle then one facing the right way.  All moves are planned in advance including facing so choose wisely.  Sieges are very realistic as well as I have had an army of 1000 men sit outside my city because they were all infantry and had no way to get through the walls and gates.  Archers can set the walls and gates on fire but upgrading from wood pallisades to rammed earth makes the walls immune to fire.  This doesnt stop archers though.  When attacking a town the number of openings determine how many units can hit the town at one time.  Each broken gate gets attacked and if you damage the walls your units can enter there as well.  With rammed earth archers can only burn the gates not the walls so you need stone throwers to break the walls open and create more openings.  PROS: diverse game with grand potential.pretty graphics even though zooming in on 96% naked dudes is a little wierd and those bucket head guys.high replayability.slow tactile game unlike civ where battles are just rock paper scissors and unit weight calculations.room for tons of improvements and expanded content and even a good start for a whole new kind of series that could keep expanding to be as epic as total war while retaining the 4x nature of civ games.CONS:random bugs as expected in early access like city name plates being transparent and backwards because it didnt load the billboard properly... happened once game reboot fixed.combat can sometimes be a little wonkylack of tutorials gives the game a steep learning curve.no multiplayer yet.half the factions are gated at 200 turns.  Play 200 turns and you unloack them all for use but 200 turns is a feat in it's self.

Early Access Review
								At last a game portraying the Warring State period in China. Or as close as it gets.First impressions :This is Early Access but the game feels more polished than some strategy game release lately. Great potential, fresh ideas, could be amazing in MP, i didn't play enough to assess long term replayability though (which is critical for 4Xs)UI :Interface is clean, and user friendly although usability is not on par with CIV, it takes some hours to get used to it.GFX :Graphics are uneven, it's great to zoom down to ground level and see buildings and people almost on scale, and overall the game look pretty. Terrain is not so good and tile improvements feel cheap (ie compared to Civ5). Each turn is a new Season which is quite cool visually (similar to RotK XI), unit details is a bit lacking especially texture feel cheap. Overall, despite these minor issues, it's still quite eye-pleasing. My major gripe with the GFX are the animations, they are choppy and the soldiers feel as rigid as the terracota army. Clashes between armies are not very epic bccause of that, and there can be a bit of benny hilling around too.Economy :Economy is interesting and engaging, it's actually fun to manage at least at the beginning, I don't know how well it scales towards the mid-late game. You have to be mindful of the satisfaction of the Nobility and the Peasants, who both can rebel against you. Nobles will contest your authority while Peasants will mostly complain if overworked/not fed enough etc. Raising armies can be very expensive, and limited income mean you have to carefully decide what to do in the early game, it feels good to develop the land and see your investments pay off after a while when trading routes are booming and your populationg growing fast.War :There are several type of units to train, most unlocked through technology. Units can stack on a single tile, where you can group them into formations and give them different behaviors for battle. The interface for managing units is a bit confusing so i hope they improve that.When you finish a turn all units move together simultaneously so you can intercept or escape enemies, if units are close enough they will engage in battle. Battles atm feel a bit wonky, especially when there is not  a lot of units around. It's hard to tell why they are attacking X and not Y or why they stop moving instead of engaging the enemy. Overall the system feels pretty interesting, but i hope it will be more fluid and understandable in the future. Diplomacy :Typical 4X diplomacy, similar to total war. Basically you have non agression pacts, defensive treaties, alliances, vassalage, tribute, etc. They didn't reinvent the wheel here. Technology :There is 4 trees that you can research in parallel, and there is a sizeable amount of techs in each of them, although there doesn't seem to be a lot of choices, i think gamers will find quickly a critical path to follow in most cases.AI :The AI seemed competent, although a bit weak. In my first game, most neighbors were seemingly scared of me and giving me money for non-agression pacts (kinda like in Warhammer TW at release). And when I attacked one of them he left 2 cities undefended which i could easily take (you can just march into a city if there is no garrison), before bringing his main army.

								Quick Summary: It's a good game that has bugs that need to be fixed and has a learning curve, but it is worth the buy if you like Total War or Civ or both.Long Answer: I love both Total War and Civ so I was excited to hear that there was a new competitor to these two great franchises. Oriental Empires was something new but still holding to old 4X styles. Taking place in ancient China was a great idea. Overall the graphics are great in regards to how many items the engine has to load. Also the ability to zoom in to eye level with your peasants and armies is great for immersion.      But that's all of the good stuff. You want to hear the bad I presume. Well first off, if you played Civ, get rid of all that you learned from it. If you try to expand rapidly. If you try to be super militaristic in the early game. If you try to use your peasants too much....There will be a lot of rebellions. Peasants will rebel if you make them work too much. Seems easy right, just don't build too many farm early on? Well then you have the nobles to worry about.     The nobles will rebel if you don't have enough authority or in other words right to rule. The number of authority you have tells you how many cities you can have without the nobles becoming angry. Early on you won't have many points in authority. In fact even if you do have authority, if your leader dies, you will have nobles come close to rebelling.     If you think these rebellions will be a piece of cake, you would be wrong. Rebels will take your entire city, convert your armies to their side, and ultimately cause you to rage quit. Even the AI has problem with rebels. I've seen powerful groups of nomadic factions grow to be the most powerful force in the game, but the nobles rebel and they are stuck in an eternal   conflict with themselves.      So knowing that, it's pretty easy to stop rebellions from happening actually. Just be smart. Infact all of the other learning curves such as trade, war, and money will be easy if you are smart about it. The only thing I can really warn you about is, don't start next to the White Di or the Zhou. They are usually the factions to become the strongest in China. They do this by taking a whole bunch of cities early on. So do not start next to them!     But that's all I have to say.

A chance famine combined with a random flood event can throw cities into peasant uprising, with relatively few options for redressing that. Equally, making money in order to expand my empire, in order to make more money was a real struggle - Creating a trading network and carefully investing in building more economic buildings didn't always result in increased revenue. Makes it hard to expand to more than 3 or 4 cities, and some of the solutions I've found are counter-intuitive to say the least.Overall - BuyReally happy with this game, despite my frustrations with some aspects of the empire building. 								A VERY cool little 4X game. It takes a zoom system similar to a game like Ruse, the core gameplay tenets of a Civilization, and adds some flair of its own for a really interesting combination. Coming in as a fan of Romance of the Three Kingdoms games, I'm excited to be able to experience this setting from its roots in the early bronze age all the way through its early post-imperial age, and it's doing a good job of really pulling me into the setting.The addition of characters (including your leader and potential heirs) and real-time military engagements, complete with a plethora of behavioral options for each of your military units, make for a couple of strong layer additions to the traditional 4X formula. Both elements are executed elegantly and feel "right" in the context of the game's other systems.Battle is a unique combination of 4X turn-based placement strategy, operational settings and a little luck, as stacks of units form armies that spread across the surrounding area of the map in real time when contacting enemies, behaving in battle according to the behaviors you've set for each unit. I've yet to get to diplomacy or mid-game economics and policy, but according to everything I've seen of the game so far, I don't expect them to disappoint.And just to top it all off, it LOOKS really great for a 444 MB download. It does a superb job of recreating period architecture and regional flora. Seasons come and go, and each is rendered beautifully. On my graphics settings, it's far from graphically groundbreaking, but it looks magnificent in a way all its own.Even more impressive is how it manages to scale everything - buildings, mountains, individual people in units - in a way that makes everything look realistically proportioned against everything else, something most 4X games don't even bother attempting. It makes the micro/macro zoom feature so beautiful. I love being able to observe the vast empire I've built from up high, then step down on the literal ground level to look at a particular city or battle up close. How many 4X games do you know that let you walk the streets of your cities? :)Definitely worth my money. I can't wait to see it at its fully completed state, it's already a fantastic addition to my library.

We pursue again this time smashing the rebels until they flee the field. But wait, one of the peasant armies defects to the rebels. But for me there are too many things that need to be improved before i recommend this game.Improve Diplomacy: I like how the enemy AI is very opportunistic, attacking you when it senses a weakness, but other than that it's very dull and has no depth whatsoever. And no meaning either. I paid an enemy 700 gold (was cheap) for 50 rounds of peace only to have him declare war on me again 5 turns later. He should atleast get some penalty or diplomatic consequences from other nations. It feels like no matter what i do diplomatically, it won't effect my strategy. I can go to war if i want. Or not. It doesnt really change much except how many units i have to manage.Improve Battle Mechanics: And managing these units is just as dull. The different unit strategies are cool and seem to work so-so ok in battle... but in siege mode it's chaos! I don't really know what's going on sometimes. Nothing makes sense and it doesn't feel like a siege at all. How can my archers light their palisades on fire before i reasearched the fire arrow? And how can a couple of peasant rebels who JUST spawned this turn, prevent my main army (who luckily happened to be one turn away from the turned city) from marching toward the city to reclaim it? No matter what I command, my army will be distracted like a moth by a light and chase after those peasants only to have them withdraw and everyone return to where they started at the beginning of the turn. Over and Over, until my main army joins the rebels. I could have crushed the peasants and the turned city but now i've somehow lost everything. The AI priorities are seriously messed up. They shouldn't auto engage like that (or auto pillage farms!). Also, very often during battle you'll have 1 unit fighting the enemy unit while your other units stand and watch, but it KINDA works if you chose 'outflank'. So the strategies seem to work, but the units scatter all over the place because they don't really follow the route designated by you until AFTER the battle.  Improve City Management:City Managment is confusing. What it needs most is some sort of citizen/work management. I completely crippled a city because i built 2 gold mines there first. Then I had no more citizens to build a farm and couldn't grow more citizens. I had to demolish a gold mine and rebuild. Instead of being able to momentarily turn off the gold mine's production. I also don't understand how to give my farmers a break, like the game often recommends me to, when i can't turn off farms or manage anything. Unhappiness just grows silently in the background and i can't really tell where it's coming from except for the very vague info you get. Make it more clear overall, more viewable and more managable.Steam Workshop: If you can't fix this game, maybe the modders will. They will definitely make it more interesting long-term.The game could be really good, and i hope they fix it as it IS early access after all. It would be a shame if it didn't improve. The Civ/Total War hybrid idea is awesome and it feels very nice establishing the first few cities and getting the trade routes up and running and all, a very good pace somehow, but then it just gets dull. It lacks overall depth. The game doesn't reward you for your choices / strategy. You just earn money and build. Neither other nations, nor your army, nor citizens seem to react to anything you do.

								What is this game? It's a Civilization-style 4X game with a more robust combat system set in Ancient China. It has tech trees, diplomacy, multiple factions with their own advantages and drawbacks, and much more. It is nearly feature-complete next to a Civ game, but it doesn't have much in the way of a religion/missionary/holy war system (since that really doesn't apply well to Chinese history). There is a bit of a learning curve. You are forced to do battle a lot in some maps, so get it out of your head that you can do the ol' Civ 4 single-base strategy and sit in a corner on your own hoping no one bothers you. You will be harassed by bandits and your territory will be encroached on. If you expand too quickly or overwork your people you'll get revolts.If you're a fan of Civilization and Ancient China and you always wished the Civilization games had a better combat system, but were always put off by the depth and length of the Total War combat system, then this is a game made for you.As for me, this game almost literally seems made for me. I'm a lifelong fan of 4X's and have a master's degree in Chinese Studies. I LOVE this game. It may be my new favorite.But here are some Cons to keep in mind:1. It's in early access so AI has some issues2. Once revolts start happening it's hard to recover at the moment3. There are some balance issues... chariots in particular are not as good as they should be4. There is a semi-steep learning curve (watch a YouTube tutorial or Let's Play first)5. The tech tree is a lot more complex-looking than Civ 5's, but it isn't really. It's cool once you get used to it.6.  Some typos and awkward grammar in the tooltips7. Diplomacy AI seems to need a few minor tweaks, and there should be more indicators about how the other factions feel about you8. The game looks beautiful but some of the factions recycle diplomacy screens, so that feels a bit cheap.For early access I give it 8/10 with hope that it may one day rise to true greatness. I say buy it now, though, because it's really awesome for the price and I want to see some DLC for this bad boy.

What a concept!For instance, building every building in your city isn't wise (or possible).  As buildings come with steep upkeep, you actually have to plan out your Empire a bit economically to get the most out of it and turn a profit.  If you space out your cities too much, they will be too far for trade between cities (logical right?).  If you are making silk in every city, then you're trade caravans won't be trading silk between cities (makes sense, huh?).  So therefore you won't get the lucrative trade multiplier on your goods.  Therefore, you need cities specializing in goods and then trading between them to make the most money.The game is highly logical in its mechanics and the way it plays.  Sieges take multiple turns.  Peasants get unruly if you're constantly using them to do back-breaking labor.  Etc. Etc.It's not without its flaws.  The game has a number of bugs, especially once you get hundreds of turns in.  Though, none have been game-breaking.  They're mostly just annoyances that cause you to reload and then it's back to normal.I think with more development this game will extremely outclass Civ and Total War.  Albeit, the intellectual nature of the game's mechanics and it's Ancient China theme will likely not appeal to a huge market.TL;DR If you like Civ/Total War and are someone who enjoys a challenge and has a brain, get this game.  You'll love it.  If you're a pleb, then don't.

								First of all it is more like Civilisation then TW. The battles are real time but you don't give orders to your units during the battle, you give them standing orders before it. Epoch goes from early Bronze age up to the Imperial age, with gunpowder and paper money etc. Aparently there is a difference between Farmer factions and Herder factions, but the Herder factions are locked until you have played the game for 200 turns so I don't know what the difference is. Its good as it is although I have two complaints. One is that there is an effect when you work a city, work as in Build buildings, cultivate farms, contruct roads and so on, where you build up a malus negative effect on the moral of the peasants of that city. The problem as it stands is the malus grows and grows as long as you work the city, and its only by leaving the city to stagnate that the malus decreases. And the problem is that it slowly increases and slowly decreases, so 50 turns of building need to be compensated by 50 turns of nothing. It needs to be rebalanced.The second problem is the balancing of battles, its not a major problem but as it stands you ocasionally get a semi-elite unit holding out against a full stack of milita. Another minor problem is the lack of bridges, although they functionally exist it just looks like you have build a road on the riverbed.Of the positives: the variety of units is quite impressive. Millita, Noble, Trained, Convict and Palace are the recruitment catagories, which alone is special. Then several types of Melee Infantry, Foot Missile, 3 Types of Chariot, Cavalry and Missile Cavalry. All having different strengths and weaknesses. For instance I found that, although Heavy Spearmen are cheap and effective in the Field, when you put them up against Noble Dagger-Axemen (baring in mind that this unit is obsolete at this point in the game) in a seige, the nobles will hold out and kill more of the spearmen then have casualities inflicted on them.The Grand Campaign is all the Factions present in their historial locations on a large map of China and Mongolia. The map is, from my playing of RotK and Grand Strategy games, rather acurate. The Factions have variety, although some are samey, they make up for this in the Grand Campaign by there vastly different starting positions. The other form of game, the Custom game, has several options for map type and environ composition, and full customisation for which factions will be present and will not be present. I honestly cannot think of anything more to ask from a random map generator, except the incusion of a map editor.In conclusion I find this game in its current form to be well worth it's current asking price. Any more features to be included after the writing of this review will be considered by me to be more icing for a well iced cake, perhaps even a cherry on top. I am hoping the devs will be added new factions, such as Korean, Japanese and Thai tribes, as well as perhaps a new epoch.

Early Access Review
								Oriental Empires strongly reminds me of a Total War game, except for the very important fact, that it does not present battles as a separate sub-game. Oriental Empires lets you assemble armies from a sizable choice of units. You get to choose formations and move them on a large map of hex tiles, with all your cities, farms, mines etc.Battles are fought when two armies meet. You can seamlessly zoom in on the action all the way and watch the individual men battle it out with the enemy. But you cannot interfere.I am fine with this. I personally want my strategy game to focus on the strategic level of a campaign and not have me fight single battles.However, the battles here confuse me. This is very much due to the  the presentation, the UI,  obfuscating rather than clarifying what is going on. Possibly the underlying systems are also more complicated that they need to be.Example: When are armies close enough to trigger a battle? It's more than one hex tile, maybe two or three. I cannot exactly tell, because of the way movement is handled. During your turn you issue the movement orders, but the execution happens after you end your turn. Then all units from all factions move at the same time and battles get resolved. This looks cool, but apart from pure visuals of the fighting men you do not get any additional information. Why do only some of the troops in my army attack? I have no idea, I have set the tactics for the army to full assault. Additional armies can join a battle if they are close enough. Again, how close?Things get really hard to understand when the battle is about a city. I had a large army camping in a city and wanted to engage a small enemy army approaching in the following turn. However due to their movement range plus the battle range – yes, they do not actually have to reach the city to take it – my army got surprise attacked and wiped out. Wait what? How did my large army with my excellent commander lose?Undefended cities have four gates and I did not assign troops to these locations but kept them in the basic garrison position. Then during the battle the two enemy units attacked one gate each. And my army met them there with one unit each. For some reason my weakest unit was selected to fight their strong unit and that was that.Now, I do not say, that all those systems are bad, I do not understand them enough. But I have my doubts. I really want a game to better present what is going on and why. Why can I not get additional information during battles? Let me click on stuff to tell me stuff.Apart from the battles the game appeals to me more. There is a technology tree to research, cities to settle and to build up, land to develop and an economy to cater for. But overall, while this is fun, it is more on the Total War level of complexity than a civilisation, and in any case it relies on you being able to win battles, a lot.I will check back with the game when it is completely done. I want to see this setting of ancient China done well. Maybe?

								Absolutely not recommended. I would love to see either a CIV or TW game set in ancient China like this, which is why I bought this game. However, this is neither of those things, although it tries so hard to be both. The combat is automated, which is very frustrating because the mechanics are very vague and the AI is completely incompetent. Vagueness is a key part of the experience of this game, because although the UI gives some information about things like combat effectiveness, replenishment, trade values, unrest etc, there is no DETAIL. For instance, I know from the UI that army "readiness" depletes through movement or combat, and is restored by resting. What is readiness, you ask? I haven't got a clue. It was never explained. A similar one is how combat is initiated - we're told that this happens when armies cross paths during the execution phase, but it's unclear how close armies have to get to each other to actually fight. For more detail on the terrible combat mechanics, I'd recommend checking out some of the other review below, as I'd just be reiterating what they said, but if you don't fancy that and want the short version: it's terrible. The AI has no idea how to use different types of units - it will let your archers/cavalry just stand still and be cut down by infantry, while your own infantry stand around scratching their balls. Enemy factions will take your cities with armies which are 1/10 the size of your garrison. This game was disappointing because I really really wanted it to be good. This is a setting which is underdone in strategy franchises and I was hoping this game would be the thing I'd been looking for, but sadly in this state it is just confusing, frustrating and unbalanced. And if I'm honest it feels as if the game was planned as something better than this, but funding got cut half way through, leaving the developers to try and polish what mechanics they already had into something resembling a game, leaving many of the planned features out of the finished product. Not recommended in this state.

Early Access Review
								This game is terrible in its current state. There is no tutorial, no intuitive interface that tells you why rebels spawn or why there is a limit to the number of units you can recruit despite having enough money. Rebels keep spawning without any warning as to what threshold of disorder will trigger their spawn and when you send armies to intercept them, they keep sending you on a wild goose chase while the enemy faction builds up its army to attack you. All this while, how your unit recruitment cap works is a mystery and you end up fighting an intense war very early because enemy factions spawn too close to your capital and refuse peace.There are background numbers that you have to manually search for to see their effects but these are obfuscated in the primary UI. There is also no indication how fast units will heal and whether they can replenish in enemy regions or not. There is no indication of effective range by which enemy units can be intercepted or reinforcements may join a fight. Although researching certain techs allows you to build bazaars for more money, they cost a ton to build relative to your early income. A huge problem is the mechanics to build up your economy do not scale appropriately to the mechanics to build your military and civil buildings. While this game is not directly comparable to Total War, the costs of early tier 1 economic buildings and units in Total War are reasonably scaled to allow sustainable recruitment during the early game when income is very limited. I have no problems with enemies attacking me early on as long as scaling as decribed above is sustainable and balanced to match the game stage you're in. This is not the case in Oriental Empires. I can see the game intends to create many interesting mechanics, but how these mechanics are related to one another is extremely vague and the lack of a clear intuitive interface aggravates the lack of a tutorial. Unless the UI is improved to present key mechanics info you need to know, provides adequate and clear warnings on rebel/disaster thresholds, and scales expenses appropriately with game stage you're in, avoid this game at all costs.

								I had waited for a game like this, covering ancient Far East Asia (Mongolia-China) and after playing a few hours on it, I will admit... I was thoroughly impressed. There are hiccups of course... the game just got released in an early access so.... what do you expect?Level of Detail: 4/5, You can literally zoom into you're towns and cities, seeing every building and the citizens doing their own thing. Farmlands actually have moving people ploughing away and bands of wild horses just graze around in their pastures. Nearly everything is possible to zoom into and see... from great monestaries to the tiny little country-side Gers and Mansions. You can also see your troops, they are individually unique (for the most part) although their combat mechanics are quite basic (charge to enemy, poke him with spear, then poke again).Gameplay Mechanics: 4/5, You're peasants build farms, mines, roads, shrines, pavileons, monastaries and chop down trees. You can select various buildings to build in your cities to improve trade, defense, peasant/noble happiness, available food and military buildings to improve your forces. You can engage in diplomacy, form alliances or vassals, ask nations to accept you as the Emperor or simply form a non-aggression pact. The Technology Tree is split into 4 groups, each can be researched at the same time. They unlock various Edicts (that you can choose to decree to give great bonuses) as well as many other economic, military and social technologies.The AI: From my playthrough, I would say the AI is decent, they would do what you'd expect them to do.... chomp down on the weak, or suck up to the strong... but I did encounter some interesting times such as an allied nation working with me to take down a peasant rebellion... but rather than taking the city himself, his forces allowed me to take it. The AI have also given decent amounts of money to aid me in difficult financial situations. I have noticed however... that the AI seem to have an almost unlimited amount of wealth as wars CAN last a very long time unless you severely out-number and out-gear the enemy faction.AI Bandits and Rebels also take opportunties to raid your farms but are slightly... stupid when it comes to a fight, they are willing to dive head-first into a fight that severely outnumbers them.End of my review, I personally think it is a fantastic game and recommend any and all to at least try it... it is NOT a combination of total War.. it is more like Endless Legends, Civilizations and Nobunaga's Ambition combined.

								I agree with a prior review. I understand this is an early access game.These are the issues:The Combat AI is in need of major work. Formation settings don't hold. An archer unit assigned to harrass engages enemy in melee instead of backing off to attack ranged. While the infantry sits idly by and watches the whole situation unfold. Archer unit gets wiped out - like that wasn't expected. Archers against armored foot soldiers don't tend to fair so well. Units walk towards another unit and then walk away for no apparent reason. Two armies will walk right through each other and not even engage. There should be a group army command that tells all the units to act as a whole, instead of ordering the whole group do something and then sit and watch the individual units do whatever they want. When units from other factions attack each other on your territory, they walk right through your walls like they aren't even there. (Pathing issues).The above issue is probably why Civ is like it is.The excessive amount of rebels that are constantly waiting to attack your cities is well excessive. And when your city starts a rebellion... you lose the whole city, without being able to suppress the revolt. I was attacked by multiple large units of rebels from the first day in the game with no units. The rebel units were stronger than the actual faction armies.The automated features don't appear to work. I set the AI to growth and nothing gets done, no farm building, no buildings, nothing. I had to manually control multiple cities by myself (which I can do), but auto governing actually working would be nice.There should also be a retreat option when in combat and a verification of your formation prior to entering battle. Field commands are needed to make the battle a little more controllable.I love the concept of this game and do believe it has potential. The price is a bit high for this early of access, and is not really something someone should spend their money on just yet. Give it time to get better and then buy it. Till then just follow.The company should not require the money to make a good game, they should make a good complete game to get that money. Because if you put out a quality product... people will buy it.I will recommend this game, but advise you should wait for it to get better.

								First of all, let me get the most important point out of the way.  This is an excellent example of a "just five more minutes" game.    The economic system is excellent.   The equivalent of "goodie huts" (from Civ) are interesting and add spice.  The tech trees (all 4 of them) are inter-related and you must use them properly if you want to do well in this game.  I love the ability to customize games.  (Remember this:  Continental map, huge, All China terrain, and seed of 666666.)  The one down side is that the battle AI still needs tweaking.  I mostly play on easy mode (most games I like hard) because of this.  I've read several of the negative reviews.  Either the writers had unrealistic explanations, or they didn't delve deeply enough into the game (yes I'm including the one with almost 60 hours of gameplay).  There's a lot of depth here and economic strategy can be just as important as military.  Polish is needed in several areas.  HOWEVER you should recall that the game has only been out on Early Access for a week.  It's highly playable now, but, if you like a completely polished game, wait 2-3 months.  Even with its flaws, it's already a lot of fun.
